title: Submedians (Easy Version)
statementHtml:
This is the easy version of the problem. The only difference is that in this version, you are asked to find a subarray only for the maximum submedian.

You can make hacks only if both versions of the problem are solved.

An integer vv is a median of an array bb of length mm if and only if:

You're given an integer kk and an array a1,…,ana1,…,an of integers between 11 and nn.

An integer vv from 11 to nn is said to be a submedian if there exists at least one pair of indices (l,r)(l,r) such that

It can be proven that there always exists at least one submedian. Find the maximum submedian vmaxvmax and any corresponding pair of indices (l,r)(l,r).
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤500001≤t≤50000). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and kk (1≤k≤n≤3000001≤k≤n≤300000).

The second line of each test case contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤n1≤ai≤n).

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases doesn't exceed 300000300000.
outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output three integers vmaxvmax, ll, and rr — the maximum submedian vmaxvmax and the bounds of a subarray of length at least kk (r−l+1≥kr−l+1≥k) such that vmaxvmax is one of its medians.

If there are many solutions, you can print any of them.
noteHtml:
In the first test case, the subarrays of length at least k=3k=3 are

  • (l=1,r=3)(l=1,r=3): [4,1,2][4,1,2] whose only median is 22,
  • (l=2,r=4)(l=2,r=4): [1,2,4][1,2,4] whose only median is 22, and
  • (l=1,r=4)(l=1,r=4): [4,1,2,4][4,1,2,4] whose medians are 22, 33, and 44.

In the second test case, one possible output is (l=3,r=4)(l=3,r=4) whose medians are 22 and 33.

Note that it can be proven that no subarray of length at least 22 admits 44 or 55 as a median.
